elements.content: Six novel complexes formed under hydrothermal conditions by uranyl ions with three ligands comprising a rigid phenyl- or cyclohexyl-containing platform, and two to four acetate arms have been obtained. 1,3,5-Benzenetriacetic acid (H3BTA) yielded the complex [NMe4][UO2(BTA)]·H2O (1), in which the structure-directing counterion induces a two-dimensional, bilayer-type structure different from that previously reported, with both the tris-chelating ligand and the metal ion as trigonal nodes. Two complexes were obtained with 1,2-phenylenedioxydiacetic acid (H2PDDA), [UO2(PDDA)(H2O)] (2) and [H2DABCO][(UO2)2(PDDA)3]·1.5H2O (3). Complex 2 is a simple, ribbon-like, one-dimensional polymer, while 3 is a nanotubular assembly built around the hydrogen-bonded, structure-directing counterions. Three complexes were obtained with trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid (H4DCTA), a polyaminopolycarboxylic acid, with different bases, [UO2(H2DCTA)(H2O)2]·H2O (4), [UO2(H2DCTA)(H2O)]·1.5H2O (5), and [UO2Na(HDCTA)(H2O)] (6). The nitrogen atoms are not coordinated, both of them (4) or only one (5 and 6) being protonated, and the carboxylic/ate groups are monodentate, except for one chelating in 6 and one nonbonding in 4. These differences in bonding result in various assemblies, one-dimensional in 4 and two-dimensional in 5 and 6. The layers in 5 are strongly corrugated, with the cyclohexyl groups pointing on either side, and their packing displays oval-shaped channels, while the layers in 6 are planar, with the cyclohexyl groups located on one side, and further assembled into dimeric units by the disordered sodium ions. These are the first crystal structures of actinide ion complexes with both H2PDDA and H4DCTA.

elements.content: Uranyl ion complexes with three ligands uniting a rigid aromatic or alicyclic platform and two to four acetate arms have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. The polymeric assemblies formed are one- or two-dimensional, the most remarkable one being a nanotubular architecture built around hydrogen-bonded counterions.
elements.clean_text: Uranyl ion complexes with three ligands uniting a rigid aromatic or alicyclic platform and two to four acetate arms have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. The polymeric assemblies formed are one- or two-dimensional, the most remarkable one being a nanotubular architecture built around hydrogen-bonded counterions.

elements.content: Carboxylates and polycarboxylates are among the ligands most commonly associated with uranyl ions, whether it be in the context of studies related to nuclear waste management, extraction, or materials chemistry. The sheer number of crystal structures of uranyl carboxylate complexes reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.31), which comes close to 400, shows the importance of this field. The variety of available polycarboxylate ligands, as well as that of possible additional ligands, is such that novel structural features are still to be expected. A particularly dynamic research field is that of uranyl−organic polymers and frameworks, in which the use of polycarboxylate ligands is widespread. Most compounds in this last family involve quite rigid polycarboxylic acids, for example, those built on the phenyl and naphthalenyl, pyridyl, pyrazyl, pyrazolyl, or even cyclohexyl skeletons, in which the carboxylate substituents are only able to rotate along one axis. Flexible polycarboxylates, with alkyl chains of varying lengths, have also been much investigated, such as aliphatic di- and tetra-carboxylates, tartrate or citrate and related ligands. An interesting intermediate case is that in which the carboxylate functions are connected to a rigid group through alkyl chains. Several such examples have recently been described, which include the uranyl complexes with tris(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanurate, and with the acetate-bearing ligands 2-pyridylacetate, 1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-N,N′,N′′,N′′′-tetraacetate (DOTA), 1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane-1,4,8,11-tetraacetate (TETA), and 1,3,5-benzenetriacetate. In all these molecules, a rigid or at least conformationally constrained planar platform is functionalized by one, three, or four alkylcarboxylate groups which introduce a degree of geometric freedom, thus enabling novel uranyl−organic architectures to be obtained. The present work is an extension of this investigation to two acetate-bearing ligands for which no uranyl ion complex has ever been crystallographically characterized, 1,2-phenylenedioxydiacetic acid (H2PDDA) and trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid (H4DCTA), the latter pertaining to the family of polyaminopolycarboxylic acids. A novel complex involving 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3BTA) is also reported. These three ligands are represented in Scheme .
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Carboxylates and polycarboxylates are among the ligands most commonly associated with uranyl ions, whether it be in the context of studies related to nuclear waste management, extraction, or materials chemistry. The sheer number of crystal structures of uranyl carboxylate complexes reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.31), which comes close to 400, shows the importance of this field. The variety of available polycarboxylate ligands, as well as that of possible additional ligands, is such that novel structural features are still to be expected. A particularly dynamic research field is that of uranyl-organic polymers and frameworks, in which the use of polycarboxylate ligands is widespread. Most compounds in this last family involve quite rigid polycarboxylic acids, for example, those built on the phenyl and naphthalenyl, pyridyl, pyrazyl, pyrazolyl, or even cyclohexyl skeletons, in which the carboxylate substituents are only able to rotate along one axis. Flexible polycarboxylates, with alkyl chains of varying lengths, have also been much investigated, such as aliphatic di- and tetra-carboxylates, tartrate or citrate and related ligands. An interesting intermediate case is that in which the carboxylate functions are connected to a rigid group through alkyl chains. Several such examples have recently been described, which include the uranyl complexes with tris(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanurate, and with the acetate-bearing ligands 2-pyridylacetate, 1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-N,N',N'',N'''-tetraacetate (DOTA), 1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane-1,4,8,11-tetraacetate (TETA), and 1,3,5-benzenetriacetate. In all these molecules, a rigid or at least conformationally constrained planar platform is functionalized by one, three, or four alkylcarboxylate groups which introduce a degree of geometric freedom, thus enabling novel uranyl-organic architectures to be obtained. The present work is an extension of this investigation to two acetate-bearing ligands for which no uranyl ion complex has ever been crystallographically characterized, 1,2-phenylenedioxydiacetic acid (H2PDDA) and trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetic acid (H4DCTA), the latter pertaining to the family of polyaminopolycarboxylic acids. A novel complex involving 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3BTA) is also reported. These three ligands are represented in Scheme .

elements.content:
Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Prolabo, 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid and trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid monohydrate were from Fluka, and 1,2-phenylenedioxydiacetic acid was from Aldrich. Elemental analyses were performed by Service de Microanalyse du CNRS at Gif-sur-Yvette, France.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

 Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O was purchased from Prolabo, 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid and trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetic acid monohydrate were from Fluka, and 1,2-phenylenedioxydiacetic acid was from Aldrich. Elemental analyses were performed by Service de Microanalyse du CNRS at Gif-sur-Yvette, France.

elements.content: 1,3,5-Benzenetriacetic acid (30 mg, 0.12 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.12 mmol), NMe4OH (110 mg, 1.21 mmol), and demineralized water (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, appeared within 10 days.

elements.content: The data were collected on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting “Paratone-N” oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by Patterson map interpretation (complex 4) or by direct methods (all other compounds) with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The sodium atom in 6 is disordered over three positions which have been given equal occupancy parameters. Restraints on displacement parameters were applied for some badly behaving atoms, particularly the carbon atoms of the counterion in 1, and those of the cyclohexane ring in 4. Some water molecules were given occupancy factors of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters or to account for their closeness to their image by symmetry. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen and nitrogen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps, except for those of the lattice water molecules in 1 and 5, and of the sodium-bound disordered water molecules in 6. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 (OH, NH, CH, CH2) or 1.5 (CH3) times that of the parent atom.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting "Paratone-N" oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by Patterson map interpretation (complex 4) or by direct methods (all other compounds) with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The sodium atom in 6 is disordered over three positions which have been given equal occupancy parameters. Restraints on displacement parameters were applied for some badly behaving atoms, particularly the carbon atoms of the counterion in 1, and those of the cyclohexane ring in 4. Some water molecules were given occupancy factors of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters or to account for their closeness to their image by symmetry. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen and nitrogen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps, except for those of the lattice water molecules in 1 and 5, and of the sodium-bound disordered water molecules in 6. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 (OH, NH, CH, CH2) or 1.5 (CH3) times that of the parent atom.

The synthesis of complex 1, [NMe4][UO2(BTA)]·H2O, differs from that of the other uranyl complex with BTA3− previously reported, [UO2(H2O)5][UO2(BTA)]2·5H2O (7), by replacement of NaOH by excess NMe4OH as a base, and the resulting crystal structures are different. The asymmetric unit in 1 corresponds to one formula unit (Figure ); the uranyl ion is chelated by three carboxylate groups pertaining to three different molecules, as in complex 7 and with an identical average U−O bond length of 2.47(3) Å (Table ), which gives the hexagonal bipyramidal uranium environment usual with small-bite ligands. The carboxylate group containing O7′′ and O8′′ is bonded in a more asymmetric fashion than the others, with a 0.10 Å difference between the two bond lengths. The BTA3− ligand is coordinated through its three arms, which are all directed toward the same side of the aromatic ring, thus giving the molecule a tripodal shape (in complex 7, two arms were on the same side and the third was coplanar with the ring). The NMe4 + cation is encompassed by the three arms and is located in the tripod cavity, with possible cation−π interactions in addition to cation−anion ones; the shortest distance between a carbon atom of the quaternary ammonium ion and the centroid of the aromatic ring is 3.57 Å, which is in the range observed for the former interactions. As in complex 7, both metal and ligand are trigonal nodes and a two-dimensional assembly is formed. Cyclic dimeric {[UO2(BTA)]2}2− subunits, with each of them connected to four others, are formed in both cases. The topologies of the resulting two-dimensional assemblies are however different, as indicated by the total point symbols determined with TOPOS, (4, 82) in 1 and (4, 102) in 7 (the two nodes have identical point symbols in both cases). Views of the simplified networks are shown in Figure . Both assemblies are molecular bilayers, but the trigonal units they involve are different from the T-shaped nodes and linear spacers usual for the building of such arrangements, which give the typical total point symbol (82, 10). The tetramethylammonium counterions in 1, which likely act as structure-directing agents, are located inside the layers, as are the hydrogen bonded [UO2(H2O)5]2+ units in 7. Whereas the layers are strongly corrugated in 7, with adjacent ones displaying some interdigitation, they have quite planar faces in 1, with no π-stacking interaction present. The Kitaigorodski packing indexes (estimated with PLATON) are nearly identical in both compounds, with values of 0.70 for the whole structure and 0.49 (0.50 in 7) for the connected net alone, with counterions and solvent molecules excluded.

Results and Discussion

The synthesis of complex 1, [NMe4][UO2(BTA)]⋅H2O, differs from that of the other uranyl complex with BTA3- previously reported, [UO2(H2O)5][UO2(BTA)]2⋅5H2O (7), by replacement of NaOH by excess NMe4OH as a base, and the resulting crystal structures are different. The asymmetric unit in 1 corresponds to one formula unit (Figure ); the uranyl ion is chelated by three carboxylate groups pertaining to three different molecules, as in complex 7 and with an identical average U-O bond length of 2.47(3) Å (Table ), which gives the hexagonal bipyramidal uranium environment usual with small-bite ligands. The carboxylate group containing O7'' and O8'' is bonded in a more asymmetric fashion than the others, with a 0.10 Å difference between the two bond lengths. The BTA3- ligand is coordinated through its three arms, which are all directed toward the same side of the aromatic ring, thus giving the molecule a tripodal shape (in complex 7, two arms were on the same side and the third was coplanar with the ring). The NMe4 + cation is encompassed by the three arms and is located in the tripod cavity, with possible cation-π interactions in addition to cation-anion ones; the shortest distance between a carbon atom of the quaternary ammonium ion and the centroid of the aromatic ring is 3.57 Å, which is in the range observed for the former interactions. As in complex 7, both metal and ligand are trigonal nodes and a two-dimensional assembly is formed. Cyclic dimeric {[UO2(BTA)]2}2- subunits, with each of them connected to four others, are formed in both cases. The topologies of the resulting two-dimensional assemblies are however different, as indicated by the total point symbols determined with TOPOS, (4, 82) in 1 and (4, 102) in 7 (the two nodes have identical point symbols in both cases). Views of the simplified networks are shown in Figure . Both assemblies are molecular bilayers, but the trigonal units they involve are different from the T-shaped nodes and linear spacers usual for the building of such arrangements, which give the typical total point symbol (82, 10). The tetramethylammonium counterions in 1, which likely act as structure-directing agents, are located inside the layers, as are the hydrogen bonded [UO2(H2O)5]2+ units in 7. Whereas the layers are strongly corrugated in 7, with adjacent ones displaying some interdigitation, they have quite planar faces in 1, with no π-stacking interaction present. The Kitaigorodski packing indexes (estimated with PLATON) are nearly identical in both compounds, with values of 0.70 for the whole structure and 0.49 (0.50 in 7) for the connected net alone, with counterions and solvent molecules excluded.

elements.content: The complexes [UO2(PDDA)(H2O)] (2) and [H2DABCO][(UO2)2(PDDA)3]·1.5H2O (3) were obtained from the reaction of H2PDDA with uranyl nitrate in the presence of NaOH or 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO), respectively (2 was also obtained with LiOH, NMe4OH, or 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene in place of NaOH). Complex 2 presents a very simple arrangement and is devoid of counterions and solvent molecules. The asymmetric unit comprises one formula unit; the uranyl ion is bound to one chelating and two bridging carboxylate groups, with average U−O bond lengths of 2.475(5) and 2.311(10) Å, respectively, and to an aqua ligand, thus giving the common pentagonal bipyramidal uranium environment (Figure ). Each metal cation is bound to three different ligands and, conversely, each ligand connects three cations. The arrangement is one-dimensional and parallel to the b axis, with a central row of uranyl ions being surrounded by ligands on two sides, which results in a ribbon shape. Both metal and ligand are topologically similar and the total point symbol is (42, 6). The aqua ligands are located within the 15-membered M2L2 rings and they form two intramolecular hydrogen bonds with one carboxylate and one ether oxygen atoms (Table ), thus likely contributing to maintaining the flat shape. The ribbons are stacked in a parallel fashion so as to give a packing index of 0.66.

elements.content: The H2DABCO2+ counterion acts as a structure-directing agent in compound 3, which presents a structure completely different from that of 2. The asymmetric unit contains two uranyl ions and three PDDA2− ligands, with the latter being bis-chelating and the metal cations being bound to three ligands, as in complex 1 (Figure ). The average U−O(carboxylate) bond length, 2.47(4) Å, is identical to those in 1 and 7; some of the carboxylate groups are asymmetrically bound, with a maximum difference of 0.12 Å between the two bond lengths. Instead of displaying a planar geometry with the two arms directed toward the same direction, as in 2, these arms are divergent in 3 and the ligand is no longer planar. The torsion angles in the motif defined by the two arms and the two ring atoms bearing them are all close to syn or anti values in 2, whereas the Cring−Oether−C−C angles in 3 assume values in the range 71−96°, indicating a move toward gauche angles, and the departure of the other angles from ideal syn and anti values can be as large as 27°. In 2, the two COO groups make dihedral angles of 16.8(5) and 7.5(6)° with the quasi-planar C6O2 unit, and the four carbon atoms of the acetate arms are displaced by only 0.010(9)−0.090(10) Å from the latter plane. In contrast, the corresponding dihedral angles for the three ligands in 3 are in the range 65.9(3)−88.5(3)° (the dihedral angles between the two COO groups in each ligand being however small, in the 12.9(7)−13.8(6)° range) and the carbon atoms of the acetate arms are always alternately above and below the mean C6O2 plane, with displacements in the range 0.333(6)−1.281(6) Å, but for two smaller values of 0.021(5) and 0.145(6) Å. Each uranyl ion is bound to three ligands, as in 2, but each ligand is bound to two cations only. The resulting arrangement is much more novel than that in 2, since it consists of narrow nanotubules directed along the [1 1̅ 1] direction and with the total point symbol (82, 12)2(8)3 (the two symbols corresponding to metal and ligand, respectively). For comparison, the simplified networks for 2 and 3 are represented in Figure . The H2DABCO2+ counterions are located inside the tubules, as shown in Figure , in which they are held by two NH···O(carboxylate) hydrogen bonds (Table ); as a result, they are tilted with respect to the tubule axis. There may be also one CH···π interaction present (H···centroid 2.86 Å, C−H···centroid 143°). The packing is quite tight, with an index of 0.71 (0.57 with counterions and solvent excluded) and no significant free space is present. Nanotubules are not a novel feature in uranyl-based architectures, since examples (some of them with large internal diameters) have been reported with phosphonates, selenates, and formate ligands. It has been suggested that the formation of uranyl selenate nanotubules is promoted by templating species such as ammonium cations. A similar role can be attributed to the H2DABCO2+ counterions in the present case, around which the nanotubules seem to be assembled and in the absence of which they do not form. Other examples of structure-directing species, most commonly ammonium ions, but also neutral molecules, in uranium−inorganic and uranium−organic frameworks have previously been given.

The torsion angles in the motif defined by the two arms and the two ring atoms bearing them are all close to syn or anti values in 2, whereas the Cring-Oether-C-C angles in 3 assume values in the range 71-96°, indicating a move toward gauche angles, and the departure of the other angles from ideal syn and anti values can be as large as 27°. In 2, the two COO groups make dihedral angles of 16.8(5) and 7.5(6)° with the quasi-planar C6O2 unit, and the four carbon atoms of the acetate arms are displaced by only 0.010(9)-0.090(10) Å from the latter plane. In contrast, the corresponding dihedral angles for the three ligands in 3 are in the range 65.9(3)-88.5(3)° (the dihedral angles between the two COO groups in each ligand being however small, in the 12.9(7)-13.8(6)° range) and the carbon atoms of the acetate arms are always alternately above and below the mean C6O2 plane, with displacements in the range 0.333(6)-1.281(6) Å, but for two smaller values of 0.021(5) and 0.145(6) Å. Each uranyl ion is bound to three ligands, as in 2, but each ligand is bound to two cations only. The resulting arrangement is much more novel than that in 2, since it consists of narrow nanotubules directed along the [1 1̅ 1] direction and with the total point symbol (82, 12)2(8)3 (the two symbols corresponding to metal and ligand, respectively). For comparison, the simplified networks for 2 and 3 are represented in Figure . The H2DABCO2+ counterions are located inside the tubules, as shown in Figure , in which they are held by two NH⋅⋅⋅O(carboxylate) hydrogen bonds (Table ); as a result, they are tilted with respect to the tubule axis. There may be also one CH⋅⋅⋅π interaction present (H⋅⋅⋅centroid 2.86 Å, C-H⋅⋅⋅centroid 143°). The packing is quite tight, with an index of 0.71 (0.57 with counterions and solvent excluded) and no significant free space is present. Nanotubules are not a novel feature in uranyl-based architectures, since examples (some of them with large internal diameters) have been reported with phosphonates, selenates, and formate ligands. It has been suggested that the formation of uranyl selenate nanotubules is promoted by templating species such as ammonium cations. A similar role can be attributed to the H2DABCO2+ counterions in the present case, around which the nanotubules seem to be assembled and in the absence of which they do not form. Other examples of structure-directing species, most commonly ammonium ions, but also neutral molecules, in uranium-inorganic and uranium-organic frameworks have previously been given.

elements.content: Three complexes were obtained from trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid, [UO2(H2DCTA)(H2O)2]·H2O (4), [UO2(H2DCTA)(H2O)]·1.5H2O (5), and [UO2Na(HDCTA)(H2O)] (6), the syntheses of which differ mainly by the base used, CsOH, imidazole, and NaOH, respectively. In neither case is the ligand fully deprotonated since either one (5 and 6) or both (4) nitrogen atoms are protonated, and one carboxylic group retains its proton in 5. The asymmetric unit in all three complexes corresponds to one formula unit, the ligand being devoid of any symmetry element, and the cyclohexyl ring is always in the chair conformation. Complex 4 is represented in Figure ; in this case, three carboxylate groups are bound to uranyl ions in monodentate fashion, with an average U−O bond length of 2.389(8) Å. The uranyl ion is connected to three different molecules, and it is also bound to two aqua ligands in nonadjacent positions. The ammonium groups are involved in intramolecular hydrogen bonds with two carboxylate oxygen atoms (one of them in the uncoordinated group). One-dimensional chains parallel to the b axis are formed, with a topology corresponding to the total point symbol (42, 6), identical to that for complex 2: notwithstanding the difference in the number of carboxylate groups, the number of coordination sites per ligand is identical in both compounds and the overall geometries of the ligands are not too different. However, whereas the ribbons in 2 are planar, the chains in 4 are more expanded, with the uranyl ions aligned into two rows on either side of the central axis, and they may thus be seen as an intermediate step toward full-fledged nanotubules. The packing index amounts to 0.74 (0.71 with solvent excluded) and no significant free space is present.

elements.content: Complex 5 differs from 4 by replacement of one of the aqua ligands by a carboxylate oxygen donor. As a result, the metal atom is bound to four H2DCTA2− molecules, and conversely, the latter is bound to four uranyl ions in monodentate fashion (Figure ). The average U−O(carboxylate) bond length of 2.35(4) Å is not significantly different from that in 4. The protonated nitrogen atom forms an intramolecular hydrogen bond with the unprotonated one, and one carboxylic group retains its proton, which is involved in a hydrogen bond with a lattice water molecule (Table ). The polymeric arrangement is completely different from that in 4: whereas two rows of ligands surround a double row of cations in the latter compound, with the uranyl equatorial planes roughly parallel to the mean cyclohexane rings plane, each row of ligands in 5, directed along the b axis, is connected to one row of cations on each side of the cyclohexyl rings mean plane, with the uranyl equatorial planes strongly tilted with respect to the rings. The resulting assembly is a two-dimensional tetragonal net, with the layers being parallel to the bc plane and with the total point symbol (44, 62), the two nodes being equivalent. These layers are strongly corrugated due to the cyclohexyl rings pointing on either side of the layer, and when viewed down the c axis the packing displays channels of approximate section 9 × 6 Å (6 × 3 Å when atomic radii are taken into account), which contain the water molecules of solvation. The packing index of 0.60 (0.53 with solvent excluded) is indicative of the presence of free spaces, possibly occupied by disordered water molecules.

elements.content: Compound 6 is the only one in this series which includes an alkali metal ion. The asymmetric unit corresponds to one formula unit, but the sodium ion is disordered over three sites which have been given equal occupancy parameters. The four carboxylic protons are lost, and only one nitrogen atom is protonated and involved in an intramolecular hydrogen bond with an uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom (Table ). At variance with 4 and 5, one of the carboxylate groups is chelating, while the other three are monodentate (Figure ). The average U−O(carboxylate) bond lengths of 2.455(1) and 2.34(6) Å for chelating and monodentate bonding, respectively, are unexceptional, but the largest and shortest among the latter differ by about 0.13 Å, while chelation is perfectly symmetrical. As a consequence of this modification in the carboxylate bonding mode, no aqua ligand is present. The metal ion is thus bound to four different ligands, while, conversely, each ligand connects four metal centers. If the sodium ions are disregarded, the assembly formed is analogous to that in 5, with rows of ligands parallel to the [1 0 1] direction connecting two parallel rows of uranyl cations to form a two-dimensional tetragonal network in the ab plane, of total point symbol (44, 62). However, in contrast to the case of 5, the layers are not corrugated and all the cyclohexyl rings are located on the same side. Successive layers along the c axis face one another through either their cyclohexyl or their uranyl groups. The sodium ion has been found to be disordered over three positions, all located on binary axes, and with in all cases bonding to two, symmetry-related carboxylate groups uncoordinated to uranium and to two or three aqua ligands, with Na−O bond lengths in the range 2.054(13)−2.42(4) Å [average value 2.26(11) Å; the average value from the CSD is 2.43(14) Å]. All three positions ensure the connection between two uranyl−organic layers through their uranyl-covered sides, as illustrated in Figure . The total point symbol of the network obviously becomes very complicated, and quite useless for all practical purposes, when the three sodium positions with their associated aqua ligands are considered. The packing index is 0.70, and only very narrow, interlayer channels run along the b axis.

elements.content: The conformation of the ligand is different in complexes 4, 5, and 6, as is shown by the torsion angles α1 = Cring−Cring−N−C, α2 = Cring−N−C−C, and α3 = N−C−C−O (the N−Cring−Cring−N angles vary only slightly and are in the range 42−47°). Angle α3 is always close to 0° (syn) or 180° (anti), but for one value at 126° (anticlinal) in 6, but the other two angles assume values which are either in the range 67−102° (predominantly gauche or skew) or in the range 143−160° (predominantly periplanar), and these are in various combinations. The torsion angle α4 = U−O−C−C for monodentate carboxylate groups is also very variable, with values ranging from 1° (syn) to 172° (anti), with intermediate values in all the range. The cyclohexyl platform thus always holds the four acetate arms roughly identically directed, but the arms flexibility allows variations in the position of the coordination sites, which, together with differences in the direction of the U−O bonds, result in different polymeric arrangements and, also, increased unpredictability.

elements.content: Six structures with ligands comprising a rigid platform and two to four acetate arms have been described. When compared with the complex with BTA3− previously published, complex 1 illustrates the effect of the tetramethylammonium ion as a structure-directing agent. However, the bonding tendencies of this ligand appear to be quite robust since, in both cases, it behaves as a trigonal node and yields, associated with the topologically equivalent trigonal nodes formed by uranyl ions, two-dimensional assemblies of the bilayer type. The divergent, pseudotrigonal geometry enforced by the 1,3,5-substituted phenyl ring seems to overcome the effects of the arms flexibility and to yield consistent outcomes, but the finer details of the arrangement depend on the experimental conditions. Although H2PDDA and H4DCTA have previously been used as ligands for lanthanide ions, with some of the compounds formed being coordination polymers, the present complexes are the first with an actinide ion. Whereas ether oxygen (PDDA2−) or nitrogen (DCTA4−) coordination happens with lanthanides, none is present with uranyl and protonation of either one or two nitrogen atoms occurs with the latter ligand. Uranyl chelation in the O4 site of PDDA2− would have been possible on geometrical grounds, but for the preference of uranyl for carboxylate donors. The extended, divergent form of the PDDA2− ligand observed in 3 occurs also in one lanthanide complex (with no ether coordination in this case). It appears that the rigidity imparted by the phenyl ring does not prevent PDDA2− to adopt two widely different geometries, either convergent in 2 or divergent in 3, the latter, which is reminiscent of that of alkylcarboxylic diacids, being seemingly promoted by protonated DABCO as a structure-directing agent. As a result, the one-dimensional structure in 2 is ribbon-like, while that in 3 consists of nanotubules containing the hydrogen bonded counterions. The ligand DCTA4− is akin to EDTA4−, and it would be interesting to compare the structures of the uranyl complexes formed by each of them, since they differ by the rigidity imposed by the cyclohexyl ring. Unfortunately, no uranyl complex with EDTA4− could be obtained up to now under the present conditions, and the only crystal structure available is that of the centrosymmetric, bimetallic species [(UO2F2)2(EDTA)]4−, in which each uranyl ion is chelated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom, the presence of terminal fluorine ligands preventing the formation of a coordination polymer. Bonding to the cyclohexyl ring prevents the two aminodicarboxylate groups in DCTA4− to be as far apart from one another as those in EDTA4−, and the formation of a centrosymmetric species is impossible. Although they are attached to a rigid platform, the acetate arms have sufficient conformational freedom to allow (together with the directional freedom associated to monodentate bonding) the formation of polymers of variable dimensionality and architecture. It is however notable that no three-dimensional framework was obtained in this study, which is further illustration of the strong tendency of the uranyl ion to promote lower dimensionality polymerization due to its peculiar, planar equatorial coordination geometry.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Six structures with ligands comprising a rigid platform and two to four acetate arms have been described. When compared with the complex with BTA3- previously published, complex 1 illustrates the effect of the tetramethylammonium ion as a structure-directing agent. However, the bonding tendencies of this ligand appear to be quite robust since, in both cases, it behaves as a trigonal node and yields, associated with the topologically equivalent trigonal nodes formed by uranyl ions, two-dimensional assemblies of the bilayer type. The divergent, pseudotrigonal geometry enforced by the 1,3,5-substituted phenyl ring seems to overcome the effects of the arms flexibility and to yield consistent outcomes, but the finer details of the arrangement depend on the experimental conditions. Although H2PDDA and H4DCTA have previously been used as ligands for lanthanide ions, with some of the compounds formed being coordination polymers, the present complexes are the first with an actinide ion. Whereas ether oxygen (PDDA2-) or nitrogen (DCTA4-) coordination happens with lanthanides, none is present with uranyl and protonation of either one or two nitrogen atoms occurs with the latter ligand. Uranyl chelation in the O4 site of PDDA2- would have been possible on geometrical grounds, but for the preference of uranyl for carboxylate donors. The extended, divergent form of the PDDA2- ligand observed in 3 occurs also in one lanthanide complex (with no ether coordination in this case). It appears that the rigidity imparted by the phenyl ring does not prevent PDDA2- to adopt two widely different geometries, either convergent in 2 or divergent in 3, the latter, which is reminiscent of that of alkylcarboxylic diacids, being seemingly promoted by protonated DABCO as a structure-directing agent. As a result, the one-dimensional structure in 2 is ribbon-like, while that in 3 consists of nanotubules containing the hydrogen bonded counterions. The ligand DCTA4- is akin to EDTA4-, and it would be interesting to compare the structures of the uranyl complexes formed by each of them, since they differ by the rigidity imposed by the cyclohexyl ring. Unfortunately, no uranyl complex with EDTA4- could be obtained up to now under the present conditions, and the only crystal structure available is that of the centrosymmetric, bimetallic species [(UO2F2)2(EDTA)]4-, in which each uranyl ion is chelated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom, the presence of terminal fluorine ligands preventing the formation of a coordination polymer. Bonding to the cyclohexyl ring prevents the two aminodicarboxylate groups in DCTA4- to be as far apart from one another as those in EDTA4-, and the formation of a centrosymmetric species is impossible. Although they are attached to a rigid platform, the acetate arms have sufficient conformational freedom to allow (together with the directional freedom associated to monodentate bonding) the formation of polymers of variable dimensionality and architecture. It is however notable that no three-dimensional framework was obtained in this study, which is further illustration of the strong tendency of the uranyl ion to promote lower dimensionality polymerization due to its peculiar, planar equatorial coordination geometry.

1,3,5-Benzenetriacetic acid (30 mg, 0.12 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.12 mmol), NMe4OH (110 mg, 1.21 mmol), and demineralized water (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, appeared within 10 days.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(PDDA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>2</bold>)

1,2-Phenylenedioxydiacetic acid (23 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (4 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 2 were obtained overnight (11 mg, 21% yield). Anal. Calcd for C10H10O9U: C, 23.45; H, 1.97. Found: C, 23.53; H, 1.90%.

[H<sub>2</sub>DABCO][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(PDDA)<sub>3</sub>]·1.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

1,2-Phenylenedioxydiacetic acid (23 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) (22 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 3, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, were obtained overnight.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>DCTA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

trans-1,2-Diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid monohydrate (36 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), CsOH·H2O (34 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 4, mixed with an amorphous material which was not further characterized, were obtained overnight. Prolonged heating of the solution results in its turning yellow, then brown, likely due to ligand decomposition.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>DCTA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·1.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

trans-1,2-Diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid monohydrate (36 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.05 mmol), imidazole (27 mg, 0.40 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 5, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, were obtained within three days.

[UO<sub>2</sub>Na(HDCTA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>6</bold>)

trans-1,2-Diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid monohydrate (36 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.05 mmol), NaOH (5 mg, 0.125 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 6, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, were obtained overnight in very low yield. Prolonged heating of the solution results in its turning dark yellow, then brown, likely due to ligand decomposition.

1,3,5-Benzenetriacetic acid (30 mg, 0.12 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.12 mmol), NMe4OH (110 mg, 1.21 mmol), and demineralized water (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, appeared within 10 days.

[UO2(PDDA)(H2O)] (2)

1,2-Phenylenedioxydiacetic acid (23 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (4 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 2 were obtained overnight (11 mg, 21% yield). Anal. Calcd for C10H10O9U: C, 23.45; H, 1.97. Found: C, 23.53; H, 1.90%.

[H2DABCO][(UO2)2(PDDA)3]⋅1.5H2O (3)

1,2-Phenylenedioxydiacetic acid (23 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) (22 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 3, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, were obtained overnight.

[UO2(H2DCTA)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (4)

 trans-1,2-Diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetic acid monohydrate (36 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), CsOH⋅H2O (34 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 4, mixed with an amorphous material which was not further characterized, were obtained overnight. Prolonged heating of the solution results in its turning yellow, then brown, likely due to ligand decomposition.

[UO2(H2DCTA)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (5)

 trans-1,2-Diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetic acid monohydrate (36 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (25 mg, 0.05 mmol), imidazole (27 mg, 0.40 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 5, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, were obtained within three days.

[UO2Na(HDCTA)(H2O)] (6)

 trans-1,2-Diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetic acid monohydrate (36 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (25 mg, 0.05 mmol), NaOH (5 mg, 0.125 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 6, mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, were obtained overnight in very low yield. Prolonged heating of the solution results in its turning dark yellow, then brown, likely due to ligand decomposition.
